column4: i've just ran sudo wpa_supplicant -Dwext -iwlan0 -c/etc/wpa_supplicant.conf  i see in termainal it says that it's associated with my mac address, it also says wpa:key negotiation completed with my mac address and it also says CTRL-EVENT-CONNECTED - connection to my mac address completed.   yet, when i open another terminal and ping google.com, it just sits there.
now it says unknown host google.com.  i cant tell what's gone wrong.
did you remember to request an ip licence from the local dhcp server?
i just followed directions from a link.  how do i request an ip?
see what "sudo dhclient" reports.
it's returning a bunch of lines, over and over for wlan0 and eth0,  DHCPDISCOVER in 1lan0 255.255.255.255 port67 interval x. then it said No DHCP offers received.  however, it should be 255.255.255.0
you have a dhcp server running on the router/host you're connecting to?
nothing magical about dchp, of course. you could always choose a network-appropriate ip address, and set your gateway and dns information by hand.
you never mentioned if you had verified that there is a dhcp server listening on the network.
when i define that manually, do i just do it in /etc/network/intefaces ?
yes, there is a dhcp server listening (router). my other machines are on it.
you could do, but best to do it by hand for now and verify that it works.
when you say by hand, and are not referring to network/interfaces.. how do i do it?
you can set the ip address of an interface with "ifconfig", and add a route with "route". those are both in /sbin, if that's not in your path already.
so, "sudo ifconfig wlan0 192.168.0.1 netmask 255.255.255.0" or the like.
and then "sudo route add default gw 192.168.0.100" or whatever your gateway address is.
im usung wlan0, so ill sub ifconfig for iwconfig
those are not the same thing!
iwconfig configures the wireless communication of the card. ifconfig addresses the network stack proper.
oh, but using wlan0 instead of sudo wpa_supplicant -Bw -Dwext -i eth0 -c/etc/wpa_supplicant.conf  is ok though?
sure, if that's the wireless interface.
